title: 107_hr5501
content: The Act may be cited as the "Higher Education Accrediting Agency Responsibility Act of 2002" and references to the Higher Education Act of 1965 are included. The findings and purposes of the Act are outlined in Section 2. Congress finds that accrediting agencies were originally meant for voluntary oversight of higher education institutions, but they now control over $40 billion in Federal student aid. However, there are already more effective and less costly mechanisms in place to protect students and parents, as institutions must be certified by the Department of Education before receiving Federal funds. Additionally, there is now more public information available on the quality of academic institutions. The quality of academic institutions has significantly increased information available, surpassing accreditation standards. Concerns arise about graduates lacking necessary skills for civic life. The accreditation process imposes costs on institutions, ultimately affecting students and parents. The Act aims to shift accreditation focus to providing comparative information on higher education quality rather than determining student aid eligibility. The Act aims to shift accreditation focus to providing comparative information on higher education quality and end the monopoly of accrediting agencies. The Act aims to shift accreditation focus to providing comparative information on higher education quality and end the monopoly of accrediting agencies. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS AND REPEALS. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to change qualification requirements for institutions of higher education and proprietary institutions. The National Advisory Committee on Institutional Quality and Integrity is repealed, and disclosures of foreign gifts are amended. Amendments include redesignating subparagraphs and paragraphs in various sections. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to change qualification requirements for institutions of higher education and proprietary institutions. This includes repealing Section 496 and amending Section 498 to remove references to accrediting agencies. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on September 1, 2002.
